instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Power (sensing?) issue related to HDD
threads.message:
This board had initially a problem with no holding off charger only and BIL button not reporting anything when pressed (led were working when you plug charger and when you unplug).
After some tests I concluded too early for an smc issue and reflowed it because there is nothing much for <SIGNAL>SMC_BIL_BUTTON_L</SIGNAL>, but I realized later when I pressed the bil button the signal was not pulled down. I tried of course another bil button. Then I discovered the immaculate looking connector was in fact the problem...


When I put back the board in the laptop chassis with HDD plugged in, it starts and shut off right away..
If HDD is not plugged, everything works great and no error found on EFI, it boots fine with usb hard drive.

Known working and tested HDD and hdd cable. No obvious damage on the connector.
Checked for shorts on the connector and none were found. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_HDD</SIGNAL> is 5V present and same with <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_HDD</SIGNAL> (3.3V).

I am suspecting something related to <SIGNAL>SMC_HDD_ISENCE</SIGNAL>, because in SMC bypass mode, the board turns on!
With no bypass, it starts and shut off right away.

Value of resistances around <CHIP>U5380</CHIP> (IHDC sensor) are ok.

What do you think? did I screwed something on SMC when trying to reflow it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Power (sensing?) issue related to HDD
threads.message:
I cleaned smc edges and reflowed, a piece of edge bonding was messing everything right where <SIGNAL>SMC_HDD_ISENCE</SIGNAL> was.
Thanks god didn't have to reball it.
Solved!
